keyTakeAways: Sean Grayson, a 31-year-old white Illinois sheriff’s deputy, is on trial for first-degree murder, aggravated battery with a firearm, and official misconduct for the shooting of Sonya Massey in her Springfield home on July 6, 2024.

Massey, a 36-year-old Black woman and a single mother, had a history of mental health struggles and made multiple 911 calls before the shooting, including one in which she pleaded for help and said she did not want police to harm her.

Body camera footage shows Grayson entered the home, confronted Massey over a pan of hot water, interpreted her response as threatening, and fired three shots, one of which struck her just below the left eye.

Grayson’s background includes multiple incidents of DUI, a drunk driving arrest with a weapon, and poor performance evaluations in previous policing roles, including issues with evidence handling and report writing.

The incident prompted a nationwide discussion about law enforcement shootings of Black individuals in private homes and led to new Illinois legislation requiring full background transparency for police candidates.
Sangamon County Sheriff Jack Campbell retired six weeks after the shooting, despite asserting that Grayson’s past did not disqualify him from service.
The trial was relocated from Springfield to Peoria due to national attention and security concerns, with a jury drawn from surrounding areas.
Jury selection began on October 20, 2025, with both prosecution and defense probing jurors’ attitudes toward law enforcement and personal biases.
During questioning, no juror said they believed police officers could use any level of force they deemed necessary; a key moment signaling the sensitivity of the case.
Defense argues Grayson was justified in using force due to his belief that Massey intended to harm him, while prosecutors argue the shooting was unjustified and reckless.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sean Grayson, a sheriff’s deputy in Illinois, is on trial for the murder of Sonya Massey, a Black woman who was shot in her Springfield home in July 2024 after a confrontation over a pan of hot water. The incident, captured in body camera footage, raised serious concerns about police use of force, especially against Black individuals in private homes. Massey had a documented history of mental health issues and had made multiple 911 calls pleading for help. Grayson, who has a prior history of DUIs and poor performance reviews in past law enforcement roles, was hired despite those concerns. The case prompted the Illinois legislature to pass new laws requiring full transparency of background records for police applicants. The trial was moved to Peoria due to national attention and security concerns, and jury selection began in October 2025. The case has ignited broader conversations about racial bias, accountability in law enforcement, and the need for reform in how police respond to vulnerable individuals.
